nested_list_tools.curry(fun, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Apply arguments to a function, but leave the last one out

Parameters:
  • fun – function with multiple arguments
  • args – normal arguments
  • kwargs – keyword arguments
Returns:

fun with one argument

nested_list_tools.on_each_iterable(lol, fun)[source]¶
nested_list_tools.on_each_level(lol, fun, out=[])[source]¶

If you have a nested list and you want to apply a function on the elements of the list, you have to go through all the levels, this functions does this recursively and applys the function

Parameters:
  • lol – nested list
  • fun – function with one argument
  • out – output list, default (for starting) = []
Returns:
nested_list_tools.replace_pattern(lst, pattern_sequence, replacement, expand=False)[source]¶
nested_list_tools.stack_matryoshka(list_to_nest)[source]¶

Put lists, that fit into the elements of a list together.

>>> l = [[4],
... [3,4,5],
... [2,3,4,5,6],
... [1,2,3,4,5,6,7]]
>>> stack_matryoshka(l)
[1, [2, [3, [4], 5], 6], 7]

But remember, graphs are the most time better solutions to this or to build a string and parse it as python

Parameters:nesting_list – lists, that may fit together, but if you want to get a good result, you should give a list

with all elements in it. :return: nested list
